name: Joel the Prophet | Jewish Heroes
displayName: Joel - Prophet of the Spirit's Outpouring
titles: Proclaimer of the Day of the LORD
shortDescription: A minor prophet whose prophecy about the Spirit being 'poured out on all flesh' was quoted by Peter at Pentecost (Acts 2:16-21), marking the birth of the Church.
description: Joel son of Pethuel was a Jewish prophet whose exact dates are debated, with scholars placing him anywhere from the 9th to the 4th century BCE. His book, though short, contains one of the most significant prophecies in Scripture: the promise that God would pour out His Spirit 'upon all flesh' in the last days. This prophecy from Joel 2:28-32 became central to Peter's Pentecost sermon (Acts 2:16-21), where Peter declared 'This is that which was spoken by the prophet Joel.' Joel's words about sons and daughters prophesying, young men seeing visions, and old men dreaming dreams, with the Spirit poured out even on servants and handmaidens, established the universal and inclusive nature of the Spirit's work in the new covenant era.
longDescription:
Joel son of Pethuel is counted among the twelve Minor Prophets of the Hebrew Bible. Little is known of his personal life beyond his name and his father's name. The Book of Joel uses a devastating locust plague as both historical event and prophetic symbol, calling Israel to repentance and announcing 'the Day of the LORD' - a time of both judgment and salvation.

The structure of Joel's prophecy moves from crisis (the locust plague) to call (return to the LORD with fasting and weeping) to promise (restoration and the Spirit). The climax of Joel's prophecy is the famous passage in Joel 2:28-32:

'And it shall come to pass afterward, that I will pour out my spirit upon all flesh; and your sons and your daughters shall prophesy, your old men shall dream dreams, your young men shall see visions: And also upon the servants and upon the handmaidens in those days will I pour out my spirit. And I will shew wonders in the heavens and in the earth, blood, and fire, and pillars of smoke. The sun shall be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood, before the great and terrible day of the LORD come. And it shall come to pass, that whosoever shall call on the name of the LORD shall be delivered.'

This prophecy is remarkable for several reasons:

1. **Universality**: The Spirit would come upon 'all flesh' - not just prophets, priests, and kings
2. **Inclusivity**: Sons AND daughters, young AND old, servants AND handmaidens
3. **Democratization of Prophecy**: All who receive the Spirit would prophesy, see visions, dream dreams
4. **Salvation Offer**: 'Whosoever shall call on the name of the LORD shall be delivered'

At Pentecost, when the disciples received the Holy Spirit and began speaking in tongues, some in the crowd mocked them as drunk. Peter stood up and declared: 'These are not drunken, as ye suppose, seeing it is but the third hour of the day. But this is that which was spoken by the prophet Joel' (Acts 2:15-16).

Peter's quotation of Joel established several crucial theological points:

- The 'last days' had begun with the coming of the Messiah and the Spirit
- The Spirit's outpouring fulfilled ancient prophecy
- The Gospel invitation was universal: 'whosoever shall call on the name of the Lord shall be saved' (Acts 2:21)
- The strange phenomena (tongues, prophecy) were not drunkenness but divine fulfillment

Joel's prophecy also includes imagery that Peter applies to the present age: 'wonders in the heaven above, and signs in the earth beneath; blood, and fire, and vapour of smoke: The sun shall be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood, before the great and notable day of the Lord come' (Acts 2:19-20). While the ultimate Day of the LORD awaits Christ's return, its preliminary signs have begun.

Beyond the Spirit passage, Joel's book contains other significant themes:

- The locust plague as judgment and symbol of enemy armies
- The call to genuine repentance ('Rend your heart, and not your garments' - Joel 2:13)
- The promise of restoration and blessing after repentance
- The final judgment in the Valley of Jehoshaphat
- The eternal establishment of Zion

Joel's prophecy demonstrates the continuity between the Jewish prophetic tradition and the birth of the Christian Church. Peter, a Jewish fisherman from Galilee, stood in the Temple precincts on the Jewish festival of Shavuot and declared that the promises given to Israel through the prophets were now being fulfilled in Jesus Christ and the Spirit's coming.

petrinePerspective.description: Peter's authoritative interpretation of Joel's prophecy at Pentecost

pentecostApplication.context: When mockers accused the disciples of being drunk, Peter stood and declared that this was prophetic fulfillment
pentecostApplication.quotation: But Peter, standing up with the eleven, lifted up his voice, and said unto them, Ye men of Judaea, and all ye that dwell at Jerusalem, be this known unto you, and hearken to my words: For these are not drunken, as ye suppose, seeing it is but the third hour of the day. But this is that which was spoken by the prophet Joel (Acts 2:14-16)
pentecostApplication.interpretation: Peter understood the Pentecost event as the beginning of Joel's 'last days' - the messianic age had arrived

theologicalImplications.explanation: Peter's quotation 'in the last days' (Acts 2:17) indicates the messianic age began with Christ and the Spirit
The Spirit is for 'all flesh' - preparing for the later extension to Gentiles (Acts 10)
All believers, not just designated prophets, participate in the prophetic Spirit
'Whosoever shall call' establishes salvation by faith, not works - key to Peter's call to 'repent and be baptized'
